page.heading: Zine Builder
page.subheading: Use Processing or your favorite Creative Coding software to create a zine.

page.heading:
Welcome to the Zine Builder!
Why? We wanted to create zines that can incorporate computer generated or generative designs. Zines are a great format to summarize information, archive ideas, and are fun to distribute.
Zine are great for collaborations. Collaborate between you and your friends, you and a computer, you and the printed page.
Typically we will just jam together to create a group zine.
You can participate by creating "WorkshopBox" and "WorkshopText" elements. This zine illustrates a few examples of how to make and use these elements.
A "WorkshopBox" allows you to render graphics into a section.
A "WorkshopText" allows you to generate text which will be rendered by the build-in text rendering engine. Your text can also be consumed by other text generators. Stand on the shoulder of giants!

page.quote:
“Zines are not a new idea. They have been around under different names (ChapBooks, Pamphlets, Flyers). People with independent ideas have been getting their word out since there were printing presses.”
― Mark Todd, Whatcha Mean, What's a Zine?

page.heading: Generative Text
page.body:
The subheading on this page uses generative text to create a different sentence for each copy. The var tag is used to expose these text generators.
Example: <var key="noun" />

page.heading: 3D Rendering
page.subheading: You can use a specific renderer (P3D, P2D, OPENGL) for any particular spread.
page.body:
By specifying the renderer attribute in the spread tag, you can control which renderer is used for that spread.
Valid values are: * P3D * P2D * OPENGL
Example: <spread renderer="P3D"> <!-- pages and content go here --> </spread>
This spread is using the P3D renderer. You can see 3D content on the opposite page.
